com.fasterxml.util.membuf

Class SegmentAllocator<T extends Segment<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.fasterxml.util.membuf.SegmentAllocator<T>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    SegmentAllocatorBase

    public abstract class SegmentAllocator<T extends Segment<T>>
extends Object
    Shared allocator object, used by standardl MemBuffer implementations. Handles allocation of new Segment instances, as well as sharing of reusable segments (above and beyond simple reuse that individual buffers can do).

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected int _bufferOwnedSegmentCount
      Number of segments we have allocated for buffers and that they have not yet released.
      protected int _maxReusableSegments
      Maximum number of segments we will retain so that they may be reused by buffer.
      protected int _maxSegmentsToAllocate
      Maximum number of segments that this allocator will allocate.
      protected int _reusableSegmentCount
      Number of segments we are holding for reuse.
      protected int _segmentSize
      Length of segments to allocate.

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      abstract T allocateSegments(int count, T segmentList)
      Method that will try to allocate specified number of segments (and exactly that number; no less).
      int getBufferOwnedSegmentCount()
      Accessor for number of segments that have been allocated by buffers but not released to allocator.
      int getMaxSegmentCount()
      Accessor for checking maximum number of segments that allocator is allowed to allocate for buffers.
      int getReusableSegmentCount()
      Accessor for number of segments that allocator is holding on to locally, after being released by buffers.
      int getSegmentSize()
      Accessor for length of individual segments that allocator will allocate; length measured in units of backing primitive datatype.
      abstract void releaseSegment(T segToRelease)
      Method called by MemBuffer instances when they have consumed contents of a segment and do not want to hold on to it for local reuse.

      • _segmentSize

        protected final int _segmentSize
        Length of segments to allocate.

      • _maxReusableSegments

        protected final int _maxReusableSegments
        Maximum number of segments we will retain so that they may be reused by buffer. Anything release beyond this number will be freed.

      • _maxSegmentsToAllocate

        protected final int _maxSegmentsToAllocate
        Maximum number of segments that this allocator will allocate.

        Number of segments we are holding for reuse.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SegmentAllocator

        public SegmentAllocator(int segmentSize,
                int minSegmentsToRetain,
                int maxSegments)
        Constructor for creating simple allocator instances. Basic configuration is used to limit amount of memory that will be used (by maxSegments), as well as degree to which allocator can reuse released segments (to reduce churn by freeing and reallocating segments, as segments typically use native ByteBuffers that may be costly to allocate.
        Parameters:
        segmentSize - Length (in bytes) of segments to allocate
        minSegmentsToRetain - Number of segments that we will retain after being released, for reuse; if 0, will not reuse any segments (although individual buffers may still do local reuse)
        maxSegments - Maximum number of allocated (and not released) segments allowed at any given point; strictly limits maximum memory usage by all MemBuffers that use this allocator.

    • Method Detail

      • getSegmentSize

        public final int getSegmentSize()
        Accessor for length of individual segments that allocator will allocate; length measured in units of backing primitive datatype.
        Returns:
        Length of segments in units of allocation (bytes, ints, longs etc)

      • getReusableSegmentCount

        public final int getReusableSegmentCount()
        Accessor for number of segments that allocator is holding on to locally, after being released by buffers.

      • getBufferOwnedSegmentCount

        public final int getBufferOwnedSegmentCount()
        Accessor for number of segments that have been allocated by buffers but not released to allocator.

      • getMaxSegmentCount

        public final int getMaxSegmentCount()
        Accessor for checking maximum number of segments that allocator is allowed to allocate for buffers.
        Since:
        0.9.1

      • allocateSegments

        public abstract T allocateSegments(int count,
                 T segmentList)
        Method that will try to allocate specified number of segments (and exactly that number; no less). If this can be done, segments are allocated and prepended into given segment list; otherwise nothing is allocated and null is returned.
        Parameters:
        count - Number of segments to allocate
        Returns:
        Head of segment list (with newly allocated entries as first entries) if allocation succeeded; null if not

      • releaseSegment

        public abstract void releaseSegment(T segToRelease)
        Method called by MemBuffer instances when they have consumed contents of a segment and do not want to hold on to it for local reuse.
